metadata.title: Facile synthesis and electrochemical sodium storage of CoS2 micro/nano-structures

sections.text: Received: 11 October 2015 Revised: 13 December 2015 Accepted: 16 December 2015 © Tsinghua University Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2016 KEYWORDS cobalt disulfide, micro/nano-structures, sodium storage mechanism, cycling stability

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have recently attracted considerable interest owing to the low cost, wide distribution and high abundance of Na resources on the earth [1–10]. However, SIBs possess sluggish reaction kinetics and lower energy density than the counterparts of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) because of the larger radii of Na+ ions (1.02 Å vs. 0.76 Å for Li+ ions) and the more positive potential of about 0.3 V
(−2.7 V vs. −3.0 V for Li/Li+) [11, 12]. Searching for suitable anode materials is crucially important for the development of SIBs. Graphite is the most common anode material of LIBs, but it could only store a limited amount of Na by coupling with a diglyme-based electrolyte [13]. Recently, a few types of anode materials such as hard carbon [14], transition-metal oxides [15, 16] and sulfides [17–21] have been investigated as potential candidates for electrochemical sodium storage. Particularly, transition-metal sulfides, which have the merits
Address correspondence to chenabc@nankai.edu.cn
| www.editorialmanager.com/nare/default.asp
of high theoretical capacities and electrical conductivity, are promising alternative materials. In a typical Na/ FeS2 battery, 2.0 Na+ were inserted into FeS2 during discharge and subsequently a conversion reaction occurred to form Fe and Na2S [22–24]. While in Na/ CoS2 batteries, two discharge plateaus in the first cycle and only one plateau in the following cycles have been detected in the potential range from 1.0 to 2.9 V [25]. Therefore, the sodiation mechanism of CoS2 in the full voltage range still lacks. On the other hand, CoS2 with octahedrons, hollow, and nanocrystal morphologies can be prepared via a hydrothermal/ solvothermal method [26–28], solid-state reaction [29, 30], and hot-injection approach under inert atmosphere [31], respectively. In view of the possibility for commercial applications, micro/nano-structures is more favorable. It combines the advantages of high volumetric capacity and fast electron transfer, benefited from micro- and nano-features, respectively. However, the effects of similar morphologies with different primary structures of CoS2 on electrode performance for SIBs are limited, needing to be systematically studied.
In this paper, facile hydrothermal/solvothermal approaches were adopted to synthesize micro/nanostructures of CoS2, which include solid features constructed by primary nanoparticles (P-CoS2) or nanoctahedrons (O-CoS2), as well as hollow architectures assembled by octahedrons (H-CoS2), respectively. As anode materials for SIBs, H-CoS2 is superior by comparison with that of P-CoS2 and O-CoS2. Meanwhile, in the potential range from 0.1 to 3.0 V, H-CoS2 exhibits reversible capacities of ~690 mA·h·g−1 for 100 cycles at 1 A·g−1. By controlling the sodiation/ desodiation process in the range from 1.0 to 3.0 V, H-CoS2 presents better cycling stability up to 800 cycles. Two distinct plateaus in the discharging process are observed and evidenced to be the insertion and conversion reaction, respectively. This means that HCoS2 hollow microstructures consisted of octahedrons are promising anode for SIBs.

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials synthesis
sections.text:
P-CoS2 was prepared by a facile solvothermal route.
Typically, 4 mmol CoCl2·6H2O was dissolved in 70 mL ethanol and then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a total volume of 100 mL. Then, 8 mmol S powder was added. After stirring for 20 min, the autoclave was sealed tightly and moved into a furnace for heating at 180 °C for 24 h. After naturally cooling down to room temperature, the black precipitates in the autoclave were collected by filtration and washed several times alternately with ethanol and deionized water. The filtered solid was dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain the product of P-CoS2.
For the synthesis of O-CoS2 and H-CoS2, a modified hydrothermal route was adopted [26]. The procedure was as follows. 5 mmol CoCl2·6H2O and 5 mmol Na2S2O3·5H2O were both dissolved in 60 mL ultrapure water (18 MΩ·cm−1). The hydrothermal condition for the synthesis of O-CoS2 was 180 °C for 24 h; while for H-CoS2, it was 160 °C for 24 h.

sections.heading: 2.2 Materials characterization
sections.text: The morphologies and micro/nano-structures of the products were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL, JSM-7500F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai F20). The phase of CoS2 and the discharged/charged electrode were analyzed with powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku MiniFlex600, Cu Kα radiation). The structure was recorded by Raman spectra on a Raman microscope (DXR, ThermoFisher Scientific, 532 excitation).

sections.heading: 2.3 Electrochemical tests
sections.text:
The CR2032 coin cells were assembled in an argonfilled glovebox (Mikrouna Universal 2440/750). Sodium foils were used as the counter and reference electrode. Filter paper of glass fiber was applied as the separator. The working electrode was composed of the mixture of 80 wt.% active material, 10 wt.% KS6 graphite, and 10 wt.% sodium carboxymethylcellulose (CMC), which was coated onto a copper foil. The electrodes were dried in a vacuum oven at 110 °C for 10 h before use. The total mass loading on the copper foil (10 mm diameter) was around 1 mg. The electrolyte was a solution of 1 M sodium trifluoromethanesulfonate (NaCF3SO3) in diethyleneglycol dimethylether
www.theNanoResearch.com∣www.Springer.com/journal/12274 | Nano Research
(DEGDME). Galvanostatic discharge/charge cycles were carried out on a Land Test Instrument in the voltage range of 0.1–3.0 V or 1.0–3.0 V. The cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were performed on a Parstat 263A electrochemical workstation at a scan rate of 0.1 mV·s−1.

sections.heading: 3 Results and discussion
sections.text:
Figure 1 shows XRD patterns of P-CoS2, O-CoS2, and H-CoS2 and the corresponding crystal structure. For either P-CoS2, O-CoS2, or H-CoS2, all diffraction peaks can be assigned to a cubic phase with a space group of Pa-3 (JCPDS No. 89-1492). The strong and sharp peaks indicate high crystallinity of the as-synthesized samples. The schematic crystal structure of CoS2 is illustrated in Fig. 1(b), in which Co atoms occupy the center site, coordinated by six S atoms in a distorted octahedral arrangement [23]. The adjacent octahedrons connect with each other through sharing corners. In
addition, the structure is reflected by Raman spectra (Fig. S1 in the Electronic Supplementary Material (ESM)). The peaks at ~288, 387, and 678 cm−1 are consistent with the reported Ref. [32].
The morphology of P-CoS2, O-CoS2, and H-CoS2 are depicted by SEM, as shown in Figs. 2(a)–2(c). It can be observed that all P-CoS2, O-CoS2, and HCoS2 display similar microscale sizes. The particle size of P-CoS2 and O-CoS2 is estimated to be 4–5 μm (Figs. 2(a)–2(b)), while it is about 3–4 μm for H-CoS2 (Fig. 2(c)). Notably, H-CoS2 is characterized by hollow feature, which is also presented in the inset of Fig. 2(c). Interestingly, as observed in higher magnification (inset of Figs. 2(a), 2(b), and 2(d)), the surface of P-CoS2, O-CoS2, and H-CoS2 are rough but with different primary nanostrctures. P-CoS2 is composed of nanoparticles. In contrast, both O-CoS2 and H-CoS2 are made of typical octahedrons. Moreover, Fig. 2(d) shows that octahedrons of H-CoS2 with the edge length of about 300 nm are stacked. High resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of H-CoS2 (inset of Fig. 2(d)) demonstrates the d-spacing of 0.32 nm, which matches well with the (111) plane of H-CoS2.
Figure 3(a) shows the CV curves of H-CoS2 between 0.1 and 3.0 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV·s−1. In the first cathodic process, two reduction peaks located at 0.95 and 0.56 V emerged. According to the previous reports of CoS2 for LIBs [27, 33], they correspond to the insertion of Na and subsequently conversion of NaxCoS2 to Na2S, which are evidenced by ex situ XRD as discussed later. In the anodic scan, the distinct peak at ~2.03 V and an inconspicuous peak at 2.4 V are derived from the desodiation process with the formation of CoS2. After the first cycle, two reduction peaks in the cathodic scan are shifted to ~1.44 and 0.47 V, respectively. The difference in terms of positions and intensities of reduction/oxidation peaks between the first and the other two cycles are ascribed to the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on the CoS2 electrode [34] and the enhancement of kinetics by the alteration of microstructures. Figure 3(b) displays the discharge and charge curves of H-CoS2 in the initial three cycles at a current density of 100 mA·g−1. Two obvious discharge plateaus and one flat charge plateau agree well with the CV curves in Fig. 3(a). The initial discharge and charge capacities of H-CoS2
| www.editorialmanager.com/nare/default.asp
www.theNanoResearch.com∣www.Springer.com/journal/12274 | Nano Research
are estimated to be 838 and 773 mA·h·g−1, respectively. This corresponds to a high Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 92%, which is ascribed to the optimized ether-based electrolyte [24]. The overlapped voltage profiles after the first cycle suggest good reversibility of the electrode with discharge/charge capacities around 770 mA·h·g−1. After 30 cycles, it still delivers a remarkable capacity of 728 mA·h·g−1 with retention of 86% in the constant current density of 100 mA·h·g−1 (Fig. S2 in the ESM). Furthermore, the CE promptly increases to around 99% since the second cycle (Fig. S3 in the ESM).
The rate performance of P-CoS2, O-CoS2, and H-CoS2 are compared in Fig. 3(c). Obviously, H-CoS2 exhibits the highest discharge capacities and best capacity retention. When the current density is gradually increased from 0.1 to 0.2, 0.4, 1, and 1.4 A·g−1, the discharge capacities of H-CoS2 are accordingly changed from 814 to 753, 738, 709, and 699 mA·h·g−1, respectively. Even at a high current density up to 2 A·g−1, which corresponds to a discharge/charge time of 26 min, a reversible capacity of 684 mA·h·g−1 can still be delivered for H-CoS2. As the current density is set back to 0.1 A·g−1, capacities of 826, 677, and 680 mA·h·g−1 can be recovered for H-CoS2, O-CoS2,
and P-CoS2, respectively. This indicates that fast transfer of Na+ and electrons can be realized by taking advantage of hollow structured H-CoS2. The typical discharge/charge curves of H-CoS2 at varied current densities are presented in Fig. S4 in the ESM. Notably, the discharge/charge plateaus show little changes with the increase of the current densities from 0.1 to 2 A·g−1, suggesting low polarization and excellent rate capability of H-CoS2. Figure 3(d) shows the cycling life and discharge/charge efficiencies of H-CoS2 at 0.1 A·g−1 for the first 5 cycles and then at 1 A·g−1 for the following 95 cycles. After initial activation, the capacity of H-CoS2 is almost stabled at 690 mA·h·g−1 without noticeable decay. Moreover, apart from the initial cycle and sudden increase in the current density of the sixth cycle, CEs are approaching 99% during the entire cycling.
To eliminate the plateau below 1.0 V and specifically study the plateau reaction at ~1.44 V, a potential range of 1.0 to 3.0 V is selected. Figure 4(a) shows the CV curves of H-CoS2 at 0.1 mV·s−1 for the first three cycles. Only one cathodic peak can be observed and the anodic peak splits into two oxidation peaks. From the second cycle onwards, the reduction peak keeps
| www.editorialmanager.com/nare/default.asp
fixed at 1.5 V. As mentioned above, it can be speculated that Na insertion reaction may only take place at this voltage. Figure 4(b) shows the discharge/charge curves of H-CoS2 at 0.1 A·g−1. The discharge/charge plateaus are consistent with the cathodic and anodic peaks in the CV curves of Fig. 4(a). The capacities in the first cycle are around 380 mA·h·g−1 with CEs of 96%. However, a drastic capacity loss of ~17% was observed in the second cycle (Fig. 4(b)). Then, the capacities slowly decrease to 190 mA·h·g−1 within 100 cycles, followed by a steady increase. This phenomenon may be ascribed to the activation of the electrode during the initial stage. From 200 to 800 cycles, a relatively stable capacity of 240 mA·h·g−1 is maintained (Fig. 4(c)), suggesting excellent long-term stability in the potential of 1.0–3.0 V.
To distinguish the reaction mechanism of H-CoS2 in the two potential ranges of 1.0–3.0 V and 0.1–3.0 V, ex situ XRD was employed. In particular, the electrode was discharged/charged at 1.0–3.0 V for 10 cycles to avoid the influence of unreacted CoS2. Figure 5(a) shows the XRD patterns of the corresponding dis-
charged and charged H-CoS2 electrodes. Except for copper substrate, the diffraction peaks similar to CoS2 are detected in both of the discharging and charging processes. This indicates that the insertion of Na+ ions into the crystal structure of CoS2 by formation of NaxCoS2 in the discharging process and its reversible extraction in the charging process does not influence the original structure of H-CoS2 to a large extent. Similar phenomena were also observed in FeS2 towards LIBs and SIBs [24, 35]. For comparison, ex situ XRD patterns of the discharged/charged H-CoS2 electrodes in a potential window of 0.1–3.0 V are presented in Fig. 5(b). After fully discharged to 0.1 V, the characteristic diffraction peaks similar to CoS2 disappear, instead of which Na2S and Co can be found by referring to the diffraction peaks at 39.3° (Na2S, JCPDS No. 47-1698) and around 46° (Co, JCPDS No. 88-2325), respectively. This indicates that the consecutive discharge below 1.0 V in Fig. 4(b) results in a conversion reaction of NaxCoS2 in Fig. 5(a) to form Na2S and Co. When charging back to 3.0 V, only one weak and broadened diffraction peak of CoS2 can be detected at
www.theNanoResearch.com∣www.Springer.com/journal/12274 | Nano Research
39.8°, which is indicative of the reversible desodiation of Na2S and Co. The typical conversion reaction in the discharging/charging processes results in the pulverization of CoS2 at charged state, which is confirmed by the XRD pattern in Fig. 5(b).
The HRTEM images of the discharged H-CoS2 electrodes at 1.0 and 0.1 V are shown in Figs. 5(c) and 5(d), respectively. Due to the Na+ ions insertion and extraction above 1.0 V, H-CoS2 nanoparticles around 10 nm can be seen in Fig. 5(c), which is in contrast to the fine nanoparticles of 1–4 nm at the discharged state of 0.1 V in Fig. 5(d) and Fig. S5 in the ESM. They are derived from the different reaction mechanisms in the varied potential windows, which is consistent with the XRD patterns in Figs. 5(a) and 5(b), respectively.
The fast Fourier transform (FFT) patterns are obtained to further monitor the intermediate products of H-CoS2 at varied discharged/charged states. In Fig. 6(a), the diffraction spots, similar to CoS2, are ascribed to NaxCoS2 at the discharged state of 1.2 V. The corresponding d-spacings of 0.32 and 0.21 nm are assigned to its (111) and (211) facets, respectively. At deep discharge state of 0.1 V in Fig. 6(b), the diffraction spots of Co (111) and Na2S (220) can be clearly detected. This further confirms the initial insertion of Na+ ions into CoS2 above 1.0 V and then a typical conversion reaction below 1.0 V in the whole discharging process of Fig. 3(b). This is in good agreement with the CV curves of Figs. 3(a) and 4(a), as well as XRD patterns in Figs. 5(a) and 5(b). Upon charging to 1.7 V as shown in Fig. 6(c), the d-spacing of 0.20 nm can be ascribed to the facet of (220) of NaxCoS2, implying the partial conversion reaction of Na2S and Co. At the charged state of 3.0 V, CoS2 is recovered as demonstrated in Fig. 6(d). This indicates the electrochemical reversibility of CoS2 in the Na insertion and extraction process. The EDS mappings also illustrate the uniform distribution of Na, Co, and S, respectively (Fig. S6 in the ESM).
Based on the XRD, HRTEM, and FFT results, the reaction mechanism of the fully discharged process, represented by the second cycle, is schematically described in Fig. 7, together with the potential plateaus: (i) Na+ ions are inserted into CoS2 to form NaxCoS2 above 1.0 V and (ii) NaxCoS2 is converted to Na2S and Co upon further sodiation until 0.1 V. The blue dotted
line indicates the voltage plateau of the conversion reaction. After charging back to 3.0 V, the characteristic diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns and the diffraction spots in the FFT patterns can be assigned to CoS2. This suggests the reversible formation of CoS2 in both of the two potential windows, 0.1–3.0 V and 1.0–3.0 V.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
CoS2 with various micro/nano-structures had been synthesized via facile hydrothermal/solvothermal routes by altering parameters such as temperature, duration, sulfur precursors, and solvents. The microscale sizes of P-CoS2, O-CoS2, and H-CoS2 are assembled by
| www.editorialmanager.com/nare/default.asp
particulates or octahedral structures. Featuring as hollow microstructures assembled by octahedrons, HCoS2 has been evaluated as anode in SIBs to show the best rate capability and large capacity of 690 mA·h·g−1 at 1 A·g−1 in a potential window from 0.1 to 3.0 V. When the voltage limit is adjusted to 1.0 V, a relatively stabled capacity of 240 mA·h·g−1 is delivered. This suggests that H-CoS2 will be a promising anode for SIBs. The underlying reaction mechanism in the CoS2 electrode has been revealed: (1) Na+ ions are inserted into CoS2 (CoS2 + xNa+ + xe− → NaxCoS2) upon discharging to 1.0 V, and (2) the conversion reaction (NaxCoS2 + (4 − x)Na+ + (4 − x)e− → Co + 2Na2S) occurs below 1.0 V. Moreover, CoS2 can be recovered in both 1.0–3.0 V and 0.1–3.0 V voltage ranges via the Na+ extraction and conversion reaction, respectively. This method by selecting suitable potential operation windows is useful to control the electrode reactions and hence improve battery performance.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text:
This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 51231003) and MOE (Nos. B12015 and IRT13R30).
Electronic Supplementary Material: Supplementary material (Raman spectra, cyling performance, CEs of H-CoS2, discharge/charge profiles at various current densities, size distribution of the discharged product, EDS mappings) is available in the online version of this article at http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s12274-016-0981-5.
